messages.text:
Question about our use of the `actions/cache` action: What's the point of having three decreasingly-specific restore keys, i.e.:
```          key: ${{ runner.os }}-test-${{ env.cache-name }}-${{ hashFiles('**/Project.toml') }}
          restore-keys: |
            ${{ runner.os }}-test-${{ env.cache-name }}-
            ${{ runner.os }}-test-
            ${{ runner.os }}-```
Why not just do:
```key: ${{ runner.os }}-${{ hashFIles('**/Project.toml') }}```
And be done with it?

elements.text: Question about our use of the
actions/cache
action: What's the point of having three decreasingly-specific restore keys, i.e.:

key: ${{ runner.os }}-test-${{ env.cache-name }}-${{ hashFiles('**/Project.toml') }}
          restore-keys: |
            ${{ runner.os }}-test-${{ env.cache-name }}-
            ${{ runner.os }}-test-
            ${{ runner.os }}-
Why not just do:
key: ${{ runner.os }}-${{ hashFIles('**/Project.toml') }}
And be done with it?

attachments.title: Easy workflow file for setting up GitHub Actions CI for your Julia package
attachments.text: Travis CI no longer offers unlimited free minutes for public open-source repositories. However, GitHub Actions continues to offer unlimited free minutes for public open-source repositories. To set up GitHub Actions CI on your repository, simply create a new file named .github/workflows/ci.yml with the following contents. When you do so, you should: Edit the line that looks like '1.3' to reflect the minimum Julia version supported by your package. For example, if your package requires Julia...

messages.text:
Ended up with:
```      - uses: actions/cache@v2
        with:
          path: ~/.julia/artifacts
          key: ${{ runner.os }}-test-artifacts-${{ hashFiles('**/Project.toml') }}
          restore-keys: ${{ runner.os }}-test-artifacts```
So if a cache for the specific Project.toml exists, it'll take that one, and otherwise it'll take the newest `${{ runner.os }}-test-artifacts` cache. This page (<https://docs.github.com/en/actions/guides/caching-dependencies-to-speed-up-workflows#matching-a-cache-key>) explains how it works quite nicely.

elements.text: Ended up with:

- uses: actions/cache@v2
        with:
          path: ~/.julia/artifacts
          key: ${{ runner.os }}-test-artifacts-${{ hashFiles('**/Project.toml') }}
          restore-keys: ${{ runner.os }}-test-artifacts
So if a cache for the specific Project.toml exists, it'll take that one, and otherwise it'll take the newest
${{ runner.os }}-test-artifacts
cache. This page (
) explains how it works quite nicely.

messages.text: i am testing a julia package that requires files from another repository. `actions/checkoutv2`requires that the path arg is relative. ideally i could just clone to `homedir()` and it would be unambiguous where to point julia to for the files. but since i can't do this i am wondering if any of you have dealt with this or how you handled it

homedir()
and it would be unambiguous where to point julia to for the files. but since i can't do this i am wondering if any of you have dealt with this or how you handled it

messages.text: You could use Julia to do the clone

elements.text: You could use Julia to do the clone

messages.text:
```path = joinpath(homedir(), "foo")

run(`git clone REPOURL $path`)```

messages.text:
`versions.json` doesn't have an entry for that Windows binary yet. The installation script is technically meant to throw an error in that case rather than failing silently, but apparently that error is not being displayed.

The script must've built versions.json at a really inconvenient time? :neutral_face:

`versions.json` has been rebuilt, so whenever the cache expires (?) and <https://julialang-s3.julialang.org/bin/versions.json> has the latest version, it should work

messages.text:
Hi, I am getting some strange errors from setup-julia with julia version `~1.6.0-0` but only for macOS: the `setup-julia` step takes about 30 minutes (very long timeout?) and then fails with `Error: Unexpected HTTP response: 403`
e.g. here <https://github.com/oscar-system/Polymake.jl/runs/2134368512?check_suite_focus=true#logs>
So I had a look at the versions.json, there are plenty of 1.6.0-rc3 links in there but all of them give `ERROR 403: Forbidden` when trying to download then. Interestingly setup-julia still seems to be able to install 1.6.0-rc3 on `ubuntu-latest`, wherever that file is coming from ...?
(First try about 7-8 hours ago, then I did a retry about 2 hours ago and still got the same errors)

messages.text: Any delays in the process, e.g. waiting on notarization, are prone to issues like this. Sascha, can we make versions.json manually updated rather than automatically? Then it can just be done as part of the release process, when we know that the available binaries are what we expect them to be.

I'm not sure how to make it so that only some trusted users can run CI with that setup.

messages.text: Following up on a previous discussion of GHA workflows becoming disabled after 60 days. Does anyone have a solution for keeping them alive? We have quite a few packages which are more-or-less in a maintenance mode currently, and I want to keep the CI alive for them.
